comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: Carol, I'm interested in this photograph because of the name 'Cordner'. It's an unusual name and I wonder do you or anybody else have any other information? Could there be a link with Northern Ireland perhaps?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Well, William John and his brother David were both Cycle Agents born in Co. Armagh, according to the 1911 Census. We just have 3 Cordner photos in total, but no other information on the family...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: Joseph Cordner of Londonderry built a monoplane in 1908 and possibly made the first flight in Ireland a year ahead of Harry Ferguson who is credited as being first and who flew on December 31st 1909. The only evidence of his primacy is circumstantial. I'm currently writing an account entitled EARLY AVIATION IN IRELAND and the only two known photographs of Cordner's plane are included in it. I wondered if there might be a connection between your photograph and Joseph Cordner as early aviation pioneers tended to have a mechanical background, e.g.. engineering, cycle or motor mechanic and such like. To the best of my knowledge the surname Cordner is unusual so there may well be a connection. Further research needed. Would it be possible to see the other Cordner photographs?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Sorry, that link wasn't the best! Here and here...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: The photograph of the garage is very interesting. According to 'Harry Ferguson: Before the Plough' by Michael Clarke (Ballyhay Books 2009), "In late 1908 Joe Cordner arrived in the City of Londonderry from Lurgan in Co. Armagh and opened up a cycle business similar to the one he had been operating in Lurgan with his twin brother Ted. It will be recalled that Joe Cordner's name has previously been mentioned as a competitor in the first motorcycle race in Ulster at Ballymena in August 1902." I suspect that William Cordner may have been a brother of Joseph Cordner, the aviation pioneer.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flattank_motorcycles] Thank you very much! What's a P& M, please?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29460210@N08
comment._content:
A "P&M" = Phelon & Moore later to have their range of motorcycles called Panther.
Phelon & Moore were the parent company of Panther motorcycles.
